Name: Police dept’s 911 operational time analysis report.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the police department’s 911 operational time analysis report

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council

Summary: This bill would require the New York City Police Department (“NYPD”) to report additional information in the 911 operational time analysis report. This bill would also require the report to be posted on the NYPD website. NYPD would be required to issue the new 911 operational time analysis reports for the period beginning January 1, 2020.
Text:
Be it enacted by the Council as follows:
      
      
      Section 1. Section 14-149 of the administrative code of the city of New York, as amended by local law number 48 for the year 2004, is amended to read as follows:
      � 14-149 Police 911 operational time analysis report. a. Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms [shall be defined as follows] have the following meanings:
      [(i) "Call" shall mean] Call. The term "call" means a telephone call to the 911 emergency assistance system.
      Dispatch time. The term "dispatch time" means the interval of time between the time the information received by the 911 operator is entered into the 911 emergency assistance system and the assignment of a police unit to the scene of the incident.
      Disposition. The term "disposition" means a police unit's report to the 911 emergency assistance system on its response to an assignment that has resulted from a call, text or incident.
      [(ii) "Incident" shall mean] Incident. The term "incident" means an event which results in the response of a police unit as a result of a call or text to the 911 emergency assistance system, regardless of the number of calls [made with respect to] or texts received regarding such incident.
      [(iii) "Police unit" shall mean] Police unit. The term "police unit" means a radio motor patrol unit, patrol officer or other police department personnel.
      [(iv) "Dispatch time" shall mean the interval of time between the time the information received by the 911 telephone operator is entered into the 911 emergency assistance system and the assignment of a police unit to the scene of the incident.]
      Response time. The term "response time" means the sum of dispatch time and travel time.
      Text. The term "text" means a text message or other electronic communication to the 911 emergency assistance system. 
      [(v) "Travel time" shall mean] Travel time. The term "travel time" means the interval of time between the assignment of a police unit and the arrival of the first police unit at the scene of the incident.
      [(vi) "Response time" shall mean the sum of dispatch time and travel time.
      (vii) "Disposition" shall mean a police unit's report to the 911 emergency assistance system on its response to an assignment that has resulted from a call or incident.]
      b. The [New York city police] department shall submit to the [city] speaker of the council [an] and post on the department's website a 911 operational time analysis report summarizing departmental performance with respect to calls and texts to the 911 emergency assistance system for the previous month. Such report must be submitted within 15 days of the end of each month, in a machine-readable format, and be stored permanently on the department's website. Such report [shall] must include the following information:
      1. The [aggregate] number of calls [on a citywide and borough-wide basis.] and texts, in total and disaggregated by borough and precinct;
      2. The [aggregate] number of incidents [.], in total and disaggregated by borough and precinct;
      3. The [aggregate] number of incidents where the dispatcher has received a disposition from a police unit[.], in total and disaggregated by borough and precinct;
      4. The [aggregate] number of incidents involving a report of a crime in progress[.], in total and disaggregated by borough and precinct;
      5. The [aggregate] number of incidents involving a report of a crime in progress resulting in the dispatch of a police unit where the dispatcher received confirmation of a police unit's arrival at the scene of the incident[.], in total and disaggregated by borough and precinct;
      6. The average dispatch time, travel time and response time for all police units responding to incidents involving a report of a crime in progress[.], in total and disaggregated by borough and precinct;
      7. The [aggregate] number and percent of the total number of incidents involving a report of a crime in progress, in total and disaggregated by precinct and borough, in each of the following categories:
      [(i) those] (a) for which response time was no [greater] more than [ten] 10 minutes;
      [(ii) those] (b) for which response time was [greater] more than [ten] 10 minutes but no more than [twenty] 20 minutes;
      [(iii) those] (c) for which response time was [greater] more than [twenty] 20 minutes but no more than [thirty] 30 minutes;
      [(iv) those] (d) for which response time was [greater] more than [thirty] 30 minutes but no more than one hour; and
      [(v) those] (e) for which response time was [greater] more than one hour.
      c. [The data contained in the 911 operational time analysis report required by paragraphs two through seven of subdivision b of this section shall be provided on a citywide, borough-wide, precinct-by-precinct and tour-by-tour basis. The 911 operational time analysis report shall be submitted to the council quarterly. In addition, the] Each report required by subdivision b must include data from the previous two reporting periods in a format that permits the comparison of such reporting periods. If there is a 20 percent or more increase or decrease in the data required by paragraphs 6 or 7 of subdivision b, the department shall include an explanation for the increase or decrease in the report. The data contained in such [report shall] reports must be incorporated in the mayor's preliminary and final management reports. [Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the operational time analysis report required by subdivision b to be submitted to the council is not required to be transmitted in electronic format to the department of records and information services, or its successor agency, and is not required to be made available to the public on or through the department of records and information services' web site, or its successor's web site.]
      � 2. This local law takes effect immediately and is retroactive to and deemed to have been in effect as of January 1, 2020.
